div.p: Added a new show to Escape: an adaptation of Daphne du Maurier's short story The Birds (later adapted for screen by Alfred Hitchcock).

I've swapped the hot and cold colours in each of the new themes Natron and Cellar. They're the same colours (e.g. Natron still uses Marrow's colours via green-blindness), I just think the new arrangements are better at indicating what I use the hot and cold colours for (indicating interactive features that haven't (hot) and have (cold) been interacted with).

I've been testing a bookmarklet that simulates colour-blindness using the Weird Waves themes, and found some combinations I decided to add as full themes in themselves—with a few minor tweaks to keep the colour contrast high enough for people with poor vision.

ul.li: “Coalgas” is “Plasm” via red-blindness (protanopia)
“Root” is “Retro” via blue-blindness (tritanopia)
“Natron” is “Marrow” via green-blindness (deuteranopia)
“Gauze” is “Sepia” via blue-blindness
“Mycelia” is “Moss” via blue-blindness
“Cellar” is “Abyss” via red-blindness

div.p: I can't guarantee that the results are exactly what a colour-blind person with that specific form would see, but the results should be pretty close. The colour transformations were taken from A Physiologically-based Model for Simulation of Color Vision Deficiency by Machado et al., 2009.

Weird Waves now uses GoatCounter for analytics—it's privacy-friendly and just provides basic anonymised analytics that are more complex that the site's current hosting provides. This is only a test: if GoatCounter doesn't receive any hits, I'll remove the script link.

Made a few small tweaks to support right-to-left scripts (e.g. if someone translates Weird Waves using a machine translation app). Toggle switch thumbs and theme palettes are flipped horizontally, and text should follow the script's typical direction (so if the page is shown in its default script, Latin, then it'll display left-to-right, and if it's displayed in e.g. Arabic, it'll display right-to-left).
Added a new series: The Machine Stops, by E. M. Forster, from LibriVox, in 3 parts.

title.div: One last bug-fix for the road

div.p: The last big problem with the site is the way it stores and recalls your data (settings and playlist). If you opened Weird Waves in two tabs and changed theme in one, the change wouldn't cross over to the other. In fact, the theme would only be saved when you closed or refreshed the page, so if you had two pages open with different themes, and refreshed each page, both pages would stay with their own themes.

The problems with settings were, at worst, a little annoying, but the playlist was another matter. Changes made to the playlist in one tab wouldn't echo into other tabs, and the version that won out was the playlist in the last Weird Waves tab you closed/refreshed. For the most part I've ignored this, because the site's really just one page (with the feed on the side), so there's minimal need to have multiple tabs open, but just to be on the safe side I've closed this functional hole. Now, if you change your settings or playlist in one tab, the changes will immediately echo into all other open tabs (and settings/playlist are saved when the changes happen, not when you close/refresh). The easiest way to check this is to open two tabs, change the theme in one, and see the tab icon change in both.
This change doesn't affect the stream widget, which shouldn't be visited in-browser and has to store its playlist separately anyway due to using an older format.

title.div: Putting a pin in Weird Waves

div.p: At some point I've gotta just stop. The site looks and works fine, has all the features I wanted, builds quickly and runs smoothly, and generally has solid code (semantic HTML and CSS, relatively readable JavaScript). Sure, I could keep tweaking the site forever a few times a week, making trivial improvements, but there's honestly so little I can do without just going in circles. Therefore, this is the really, truly final dev update on Weird Waves. I have other projects I need to focus on! When those go live, I might post about them here. Beyond that, don't expect to see any updates except the occasional new shows. It's time for me to get other shit done.

Fixed a bug caused by a recent code change that broke the auto-play setting. I've also streamlined the code a little, one side-effect of which is that the stats in About no longer include the total hours of audio in the archive.

This one's been a long time coming: about half the themes have updated colours: small tweaks to one colour (Goop, Flame, Abyss, and Marrow); Silver's lightened up even more; Org's now green and grey; Dust's a lot more reddish; and the default Light theme's been overhauled completely. I felt like some were too similar and others just had minor or major problems.
Fixed some bugs with importing shows or adding random shows using the “+ Show/Banger” buttons. These (mostly) didn't affect how the app worked, they just caused errors behind the scenes.

I've made a few tweaks you won't see, and one you might: I've removed a few shows from the bangers list (which is used to pick featured shows and when you click the “+ Banger” button in the Booth). One was a script read I recorded of a lost Quiet, Please episode—I tagged it because I like the script and want to give it more exposure, but my reading's not up to the same standards. The rest were all the second or later parts of multi-part series, e.g. The Mercury Theatre #17: The War of the Worlds, part 2. It never felt right that you could randomly roll a show from the middle of a story.

Update: Just done a bunch more behind-the-scenes trimming. We are now firmly in the “cleanup and refactoring” part of the cycle of Weird Waves development. This might really be it for major Weird Waves updates—I've resolved every big question mark left in the code. I know I've said I'm done so many times, but those were cases of abandoning something functional, but rough. This time, if I wanted to make more major changes (besides adding shows) I'd have to start cutting things instead of adding or tweaking them. We'll see!

Thanks to the incredible power of the niche, obscure templating language eXtensible Stylesheet Language (XSLT), you can see a preview of the news feed as a web page in your browser! In fact, if you clicked through to the Feed from the main Weird Waves page then you're looking at the preview right now. I decided to make the most of this change by fleshing out the feed with a lotta past posts, including some very early blog posts.

Unfortunately, this move forced me to change the feed's file extension from .rss to .xml so browsers open it as a page instead of trying to download the raw file. This'll break the connection for anyone subscribed to the old feed. I can't do anything about that other than put a big alert in the old file pointing people to the new one and wait a while before deleting it.

Finally, I changed the feed type from RSS to Atom, which is a slightly more robust spec. This isn't gonna cause problems, since basically any feed reader that can read the former can read the latter, but I did have to update a few little bits and pieces around the site.

I think the latest burst of activity on this site's mostly over, now that I've fixed the long-term issues (a few accessibility and rendering problems, persistent low-level bugs, and the stream widget).

I've found that Weird Waves no longer works as a browser source in the Open Broadcaster Software (OBS)—the code's too modern for OBS' outdated mini-browser and OBS makes it a pain to see what's happening under a browser source's hood, so I've just added a note to the Streaming section explaining the situation (and that there's no real solution).

Update: Okay, I couldn't leave the OBS situation like that, so I pulled up the code from the last time I know Weird Waves worked on stream and cut it down to a stream widget (see Streaming for more info). It shares stored settings etc. with the web version, but has a separate playlist, due to its outdated code.
I've improved the accessibility of the icon buttons and loading spinners by using aria-label attributes.
Update: I've also improved the accessibility of pressed buttons so they're still focusable and can still be read in order, instead of being completely disabled.
Added 6 new themes in the Settings section: Pico, Sepia, Abyss, Retro, Marrow, and Org.

Fixed a bug with the audio seek bar where it would keep returning to the current audio position instead of letting you drag it to a different time under certain conditions. Also fixed a bug where a nav link would stay selected if you clicked one of them and then clicked “Back” to the landing page.

title.div: Blog Post: Weird Waves WIP 2: New Layout, New Shows

div.p: Here's another little update on Weird Waves, since I did a little bit more work on it since the last post!
The first thing is, it's got the barest skeleton of a layout now: sections in different tabs (but on the same page so the audio keeps running). Here are the different sections so far:

li.p: About, which has basic info about the site and about each section.
Schedule, which lists all the shows on the schedule by weekday/weekend block.

Forecast, which has the big tables for exact showtimes every day, which should track your local timezone (but no matter where you are, the station should play the same show at a single point in time).

Archive, which lists all the shows by series. Right now there are 2 series, both radio play anthologies from the middle of last century: Quiet, Please and Suspense. There's a position: sticky sidebar on the left with the series info, then a list on the right side that has all the show details per series.
News (also the default section), which has some lorem ipsum test posts (probably way longer than most news updates I'd add).

FAQ, which has some lorem ipsum test Q&As. Further along I'm probably gonna just show the site to a bunch of people and ask for any questions they have and see whether anything shakes out as actually frequently asked questions, but for now this is gonna be blank.
Help, which has a few questions and answers for tech issues (which basically boil down to “try refreshing the page”).

div.p: The second thing is, it's got some new shows. I found out about Suspense when someone recommended me the episode Fugue in C Minor (starring Vincent Price and Ida Lupino), which has a really, really obvious first twist and then takes a bit of a fuckin swerve in the last few minutes. It's on the schedule this weekend (along with The House in Cypress Canyon, another decent horror story from the series).

It's kinda hard to find episode summaries for the series, but I found a blog with episode reviews and picked out ~80 more shows from their “Best of Suspense” post categories… out of the 500 in that category (it's more of a thriller series than a horror series). I dunno exactly how many of those'll actually be a good fit for Weird Waves, but they were about evenly split between a “probably” list and a “maybe” list. A lot of the ones I didn't pick were noir-ish murder plots, or adultery plots that led to murder, or fraud or embezzlement plots that led to murder, or…
Also every Suspense show seems to have ads for the same vineyard in it (Roma Wines, which sponsored the series for a while). Right now I think it's kinda funny, so I'm leaving them in.

Lastly, I added a spoiler effect on the content notes for each show (only the ones with spoilery notes). I tried with :hover, then ::selection, but neither was mobile-friendly, and I couldn't do the checkbox hack because show info gets duplicated and you can't have more than one checkbox with the same ID. There were a few fixes I could've done with javascript, but I wanted to keep it simple, so I just went with <details>/<summary> widgets—specifically set up so when you click the <summary>, it disappears, leaving the irreversibly-revealed <details>. It's a neat space-saving effect.

So, what's left to do? Pretty much everything on the to-do list on the first post I made about Weird Waves. Still, even just the basic layout's a big step forwards in how the app feels. My plan's to have it all set up and be well into beta by the start of October, hopefully just tweaking things and adding more and more shows by that point.

Here's a little javascript web app I'm working on: Weird Waves, a fake online radio station for horror audiobooks and radio plays! I dunno how far off the final app is. This post's just an explanation of how it works.

The idea: What's a fake online radio station? I mean a simple web app that plays audio shows every hour on the hour—so simple it can run on static hosting (no need for server-side scripts or a database). You go to the site, you click a button labelled “tune in”, and it starts playing the current show in the schedule. It starts from the point in the show when you arrive, not the beginning of the show, and it plays the same show no matter what timezone you're in. For instance:

ul.li: You arrive at 10:15. The app starts playing the 10 o'clock show, from 15 minutes in.
You arrive 10:45. The app starts playing the intermission track.
You arrive at 10:59 and let the clock tick past 11:00. First you hear the intermission track, then at 11 o'clock the next show starts.

div.p: What about those horror audiobooks and radio plays? Here's the kinda stuff I mean:

ul.li: episodes of old horror radio anthologies like Quiet, Please, if they're public domain (or if they might as well be)
other radio series dedicated to the public domain, like Seeing Ear Theatre or Mind Webs (only some/a few of these episodes fit into “horror”, but there's a bunch of sci-fi ones too)
serial or anthology horror podcast episodes released under Creative Commons (CC) licenses, like The Magnus Archives, The Silt Verses, or Pseudopod
horror audiobooks off places like LibriVox (mixed quality, but some of them are decent), which have readings of older (mostly 19th/early 20th-century) novels and short stories
hopefully, book readings from people's youtube channels, if they're okay with it (again, mixed quality, but there's e.g. some real good dry readings of Thomas Ligotti's short stories)

div.p: How does it work? The app works off a weekly schedule that's split into two blocks:

li.p: Weekday, a block of 4 shows that runs on repeat every day from Monday to Friday. This block shifts by 1 show every midnight (e.g. if you listen at 10 p.m. on Monday you'll hear one show, and if you listen at 10 p.m. on Tuesday you'll hear the next show, and so on).
Weekend, a block of 6 shows that runs on repeat every Saturday and Sunday. This runs the same on both days.

div.p: The blocks can actually be any number of shows long, but it's neater if they divide evenly into 24 (for 24 hours). Those numbers are 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 12, or 24 shows per block.
Each schedule is a .json file stored separate from the script that contains some info about the schedule, plus the lists of shows for each block:

The script fetches schedules from the server using their filenames. Each schedule file has a name in this format: schedule-YYYY-MM-DD.json, where YYYY-MM-DD is the date of that week's Monday (in the station's timezone). If the script fails to fetch the schedule then it goes with a default schedule written into the script file itself.
Here's what schedule.info is used for:

dl.dd: Each schedule gets a name that goes in a heading near the top of the app page. If a schedule's got a theme (e.g. underground horror, cosmic horror, dream horror) then that theme can go in the title somehow.
Each schedule gets a single paragraph of description. In future I might change this to allow multiple paragraphs.
Each week has its own intermission track. The schedule provides the filename and the script plays that file between shows.

div.p: schedule.weekday and schedule.weekend list the shows in each block. For each show, they have the filename and an ID that points to its metadata, which is written on the app page. For instance, the ID qp-001 points to this metadata:

pre.code:
• Nothing Behind the Door
    Episode
    Quiet, Please #1
    Blurb
    Bank robbers try to hide the money in a mountain shed that contains nothing. Literally nothing.
    Notes
    none
    Airdate
    1947-06-08

div.p: Which looks (kinda) like this on the page:

dl.dd: Bank robbers try to hide the money in a mountain shed that contains nothing. Literally nothing.

div.p: Since the metadata's gonna be on the page anyway, I don't need to put show metadata in the schedule file, just a pointer to the metadata on the page. That keeps schedule files small and simple.

The player: Once the player's got the schedule (weekly or default), it can start playing audio. It starts playing when you tune in. Like I explained up above, it follows a set schedule with shows starting every hour on the hour, so if you arrive at X minutes past the hour then the app starts playing the track X minutes in.
There's a little issue right now where if you and arrive in the intermission then the player might play the final seconds of the last show before starting the intermission, but that's not a big deal.
Finally, there's a few controls: a mute/unmute button and a volume slider.
Everything else: The rest of the app's gonna have different sections in tabs on the same page (putting everything on one page means the audio won't get broken by navigating between pages):

ul.li: Forecast: lists of all the shows in the current schedule, split by whether they're in the weekday or weekend block, plus tables of the upcoming shows hour by hour.

Archive: lists of all the metadata for every show and series that's been broadcast (or has been added on the current schedule): descriptions, sources, content notes, license info, that kinda stuff. The app pulls this to build the info for the currently-playing show and the forecast lists.
About, News, and FAQ: pretty much what they sound like.
a few other minor things

div.p: What comes next: The player's pretty much done, I think. It's ~11 KB of javascript, including explanatory comments, and I think all the moving parts are working. There's one thing I need to test with the forecast tables (at the end of each day in your timezone, the now-empty table should be removed from the page).
Here's the to-do list:

ul.li: (maybe) allow more than 1 paragraph in schedule descriptions
(maybe) add fade-in/out on intermission audio
listen to a more podcast episodes, radio plays, and audiobooks
update the content notes on the shows I've already added
set up all the other sections besides the Forecast and Archive
add styles, icons, and a proper favicon
write/rewrite the text in tune with the radio horror vibe

div.p: It's an alpha/proof of concept right now! And I'm working on it when I have the time, so I dunno exactly when it'll be ready.
